message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results indicate a diagnosis of mucolipidosis II (I-cell disease), which is caused by a defect in the targeting of lysosomal enzymes. Option C describes this mechanism, stating that lysosomal enzymes are secreted from cells instead of being targeted to lysosomes due to a lack of mannose phosphorylation on N-linked glycoproteins. Option A describes Niemann-Pick disease, which results from accumulation of sphingomyelin in lysosomes. Option B describes Tay-Sachs disease, which results from impaired hydrolysis of GM2-ganglioside. Option D describes a hypothetical condition that is not related to the patient’s symptoms or laboratory results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the presence of a lysosomal storage disease. The decreased N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase activity within the leukocytes suggests that lysosomal enzymes are not targeted to lysosomes as a result of a lack of mannose phosphorylation on N-linked glycoproteins. This describes the mechanism of a condition called Mucolipidosis II (also known as I-cell disease).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the blood test results suggest that he has mucopolysaccharidosis type II (Hunter syndrome). This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a lack of the enzyme iduronate sulfatase, resulting in the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) in lysosomes. The lack of mannose phosphorylation on N-linked glycoproteins causes the lysosomal enzymes to be secreted from the cells instead of being targeted to lysosomes. Option A describes Niemann-Pick disease, option B describes Tay-Sachs disease, and option D describes glycogen storage disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest that the patient has Mucolipidosis II. This is a lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency of GlcNAc phosphotransferase, which is responsible for the addition of mannose-6-phosphate to lysosomal enzymes. Without this addition, the enzymes are not targeted to lysosomes and are secreted from the cells instead. This leads to an accumulation of undegraded material in the lysosomes, causing cellular dysfunction and organ damage. The other answer choices are not consistent with the patient's symptoms or laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Mucolipidosis type II, also known as I-cell disease, which is caused by a deficiency of GlcNAc phosphotransferase. This enzyme normally targets lysosomal enzymes to lysosomes, but without it, lysosomal enzymes are secreted from cells instead of being targeted to lysosomes. This causes accumulation of substances in cells and leads to the symptoms. Option A describes Niemann-Pick disease, option B describes Tay-Sachs disease, and option D describes glycogen storage diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest a deficiency in N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase activity, which is required for adding mannose 6-phosphate to lysosomal enzymes, leading to their proper targeting to lysosomes. Option (C) describes this mechanism. The other options are not related to this specific enzyme deficiency or symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory test results suggest the patient has Mucolipidosis Type II (I-cell Disease), which is caused by a deficiency of N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase, an enzyme that is responsible for the addition of mannose-6-phosphate to lysosomal enzymes. As a result, lysosomal enzymes are not targeted to lysosomes and are secreted outside the cell. This leads to the accumulation of undigested material in lysosomes and subsequent cellular dysfunction. Option A describes Niemann-Pick disease, option B describes Tay-Sachs disease, and option D describes Glycogen storage disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described match those of I-cell disease, which is due to the impaired targeting of lysosomal enzymes to lysosomes. This is caused by a deficiency of N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase (GNPT), which results in the lack of mannose phosphorylation on N-linked glycoproteins. This defect prevents lysosomal enzymes (including those involved in the breakdown of cellular debris) from being targeted to lysosomes, leading to their secretion outside of the cell. This, in turn, leads to the accumulation of cellular debris in the lysosomes, resulting in the many symptoms seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest an inherited lysosomal storage disease, specifically mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS). The decreased GlcNAc phosphotransferase activity within the leukocytes indicates that the lysosomal enzymes are secreted from the cells instead of being targeted to lysosomes because of lack of mannose phosphorylation on N-linked glycoproteins, which is characteristic of MPS type II (Hunter syndrome). Option A describes Niemann-Pick disease, option B describes Tay-Sachs disease, and option D describes pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, which are not consistent with the patient’s symptoms and lab results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with mucopolysaccharidosis type II (Hunter syndrome), which is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate sulfatase. The mechanism involves the improper targeting of lysosomal enzymes due to a lack of mannose phosphorylation. Option A describes Niemann-Pick disease, Option B describes Tay-Sachs disease, and Option D describes a type of glycogen storage disease, none of which match the patient’s symptoms.
